title: Tom Lake / Ann Patchett
text:
finished 2/29/24
i don’t often read fiction books that make me feel as understood or perceived as this book did. it’s about three daughters listening to their mom’s story of a summer romance with a famous actor years ago. they are all at home because of the pandemic, and having to find ways to entertain themselves. it’s told from the mom’s perspective, and she talks about her daughters and how to give them pieces of her past self and also keep some for herself and the differences between her daughters and none of this makes a lot of sense but this book was so wonderful and it just made me feel heard.

title: A Court of Mist and Fury / Sarah J. Maas
text:
finished 6/10/23
yeah this was also pretty dumb, i skimmed most of it.

title: Tom Lake / Ann Patchett
text:
finished 2/29/24
i don’t often read fiction books that make me feel as understood or perceived as this book did. it’s about three daughters listening to their mom’s story of a summer romance with a famous actor years ago. they are all at home because of the pandemic, and having to find ways to entertain themselves. it’s told from the mom’s perspective, and she talks about her daughters and how to give them pieces of her past self and also keep some for herself and the differences between her daughters and none of this makes a lot of sense but this book was so wonderful and it just made me feel heard.

title: A Court of Thorns and Roses / Sarah J. Maas
text:
finished 6/4/23
this book was one i had resisted reading for a long time because it’s so controversial and didn’t really seem like something up my alley. i really did not like feyre (also how tf do you say that name) - she just made everything worse and generally was just a whiner. there were definitely some parts that were good plot-wise and the villain was fantastic, but overall i skimmed this one.

title: American Gods / Neil Gaiman
text:
finished 12/28/23
definitely adding this one to my re-read list. the story is so complex, and it’s really impressive how given that, the story is still clear and easy to understand. i love the characters because even though they are supposed to be gods, they are really closer to real people. they have flaws and and can die and want to be loved. i want to read the comic because i wonder how the visuals in my head compare to how Gaiman envisioned them. i don’t know, i really liked this one.

title: Babel: An Arcane History / R. F. Kuang
text:
finished 2/20/24
this was brilliant. the characters are so dense and real and the story is intriguing and full of mystery and adventure and surprises and i loved it. i especially loved how love was portrayed- the themes of navigating platonic love when the other person has huge differences of opinion or just generally when rifts appear in a friendship are so well done. also, the discussions of colonialism and how not to be blind in your privilege are well expanded and really well navigated. definitely the second half of the book got way more adventurous and exciting than i thought it would, just based on the slower pace of the beginning, but it made sense with the building presence of the Hermes Society and things just finally becoming unavoidable. overall extraordinary.

title: Becoming / Michelle Obama
text:
finished 1/16/23
Made me and my icy heart cry like a baby. A realistic story about a person who refuses to be a shadow, and is endlessly driven to use her platform for action in a society that resists with all its strength. Also, the pictures are so cute.

title: The Bean Trees / Barbara Kingsolver
text:
finished 10/24/23
mothers and daughters and the love between them. another brilliant one from barbara kingsolver.
